PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Brian Schlining
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: QuickOpen is a plugin designed to quickly open any file in the current directory by just typing in a few characters of the filename you want to open. It's similar to CommandT for Vim (https://wincent.com/products/command-t) and TextMate's (http://macromates.com/) quick open ability. Unlike the FastOpen and OpenIt jEdit plugins, it does not use jEdit's ProjectViewer plugin or require you to configure a source path; instead it allows quick opening of the files, including those in the subdirectories, in the currently selected directory in jEdit's file browser.

PLUGIN.NAME: Recent
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Rudi Widmann
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The recent plugin stores all edit actions in a table in a dockable window. It recordes actions which are invoked by plugin, macro or built-in actions. The user invokes an action by clicking it in a dockable window. Additionally, it provides a buffer history

PLUGIN.NAME: RecentBufferSwitcher
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Michael Thornhill
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: RecentBufferSwitcher is a plugin which allows fast changing of a buffer to the most recently viewed buffer. Activating the plugin produces a dialog listing all open buffers in most recently viewed order. This functionality is commonly mapped to the Ctrl-Tab shortcut in other editors (Komodo, VS.Net, Ultra-Edit etc.).

PLUGIN.NAME: RecursiveOpen
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Lee Turner
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: This is a plugin for the jEdit file system browser that allows you to recursively open files. This mean that you can select a directory in the file system browser and Recursive Open will traverse the whole directory structure starting at the directory you have selected and open the files that it finds. The files that it opens are determined by the filter specified or the jEdit modes.

PLUGIN.NAME: Rename
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Brad Mace
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The Rename plugin allows you to rename dockable windows, actions, plugins, and option panes. This is useful for shortening the names of docked windows and for translating GUI elements into your native language.

PLUGIN.NAME: Reopen
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Eric Le Lay
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
The Reopen plugin provides a "reopen" action for reopening recently closed buffers, much like web-browsers reopen tabs.
Contents of dirty buffers are saved.
History, buffer-local properties are not saved.

PLUGIN.NAME: RETest
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Steve Jakob
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The RETest plugin can be used to test regular expressions against a given test string using the regexp package supplied with Java. The plugin also supplies integrated HTML help on RE syntax.

PLUGIN.NAME: RFCFullIndex
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Matthieu Casanova
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The full lucene index of RFC to use with RFCReader plugin

PLUGIN.NAME: RFCReader
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Matthieu Casanova
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The RFC reader is a plugin that tries to make RFC reading more pleasant. It provides the openRFC action to open any RFC from the Internet, and some fold handling by page or chapters.

PLUGIN.NAME: RhinoPlugin
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Matthieu Casanova
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The RhinoPlugin contains rhino library. It is a library plugin that is used by other plugins.

PLUGIN.NAME: RubyPlugin
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Robert McKinnon
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The Ruby Editor Plugin converts jEdit into an intelligent Ruby editor. This includes a SideKick parser service and a Ruby API Documentation browser. Focused on programmer productivity, the plugin lets you manipulate Ruby code at the syntax level. Many features will be familiar to users of the IntelliJ IDEA IDE for Java.

PLUGIN.NAME: SaxonPlugin
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Eric Le Lay
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
SaxonPlugin provides the Saxon XSLT and XQuery Processor from Saxonica Limited packaged as a jEdit plugin.
It is used by the XSLT and XQuery plugins.

PLUGIN.NAME: ScalacPlugin
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Vlad Seryakov
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The ScalacPlugin is embedded Scala compiler that runs inside jEdit's JVM which results in faster compilation times because no external jvm is called. It is integrated with Console and ErrorList plugins to handle output and error navigation.

PLUGIN.NAME: Scheme
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Nigel Galloway
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
This plugin integrates the Scheme R4 implementation produced by J. Engel to demonstrate Oolong into jEdit:
* Integrates the classloader with jEdit's JARClassLoader * Integrate with Console to provide a Scheme Interpreter Shell * Integrate with jEdit's PluginManager to enable Scheme Libraries to be distributed in Plugins

PLUGIN.NAME: ScriptEnginePlugin
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Eric Berry
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
ScriptEnginePlugin Description
The ScriptEnginePlugin provides an easy to use and easy to implement framework that makes scripting.dev.java.net ScriptEngines usable inside of jEdit.
It provides a ScriptEngineService which allows this plugin to pick up any ScriptEngines (installed separately) that are in other plugins.
It also provides 2 convenient methods for executing the current buffer or executing the currently selected text. Both of these methods provide the standard macro variables in the ScriptContext making them available to any scripts executed.

PLUGIN.NAME: Sessions
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Steve Jakob
Dirk Moebius
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The Sessions plugin maintains lists of open files - called sessions (aka workspaces) - and offers some functions to switch between them.

PLUGIN.NAME: ShortcutDisplay
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Jeffrey C. Hoyt
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: This plugin causes a pop up to be displayed whenever the user presses a shortcut prefix. The pop up contains all the possible completions and the name of the action. The idea here is to help us mortals learn more of the built-in functionality jEdit has, or to make use of more of them even when we don't remember the keyboard shortcuts.

PLUGIN.NAME: ShortcutSaver
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Carmine Lucarelli
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The ShortcutSaver plugin provides 20 configurable actions, allowing for different key mappings for different edit modes. You can assign a default action when no edit mode specific action is assigned, and assign multiple actions to a single shortcut (shown in a popup list or run as a chain).

PLUGIN.NAME: SideKick
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Dale Anson
Alan Ezust
Slava Pestov
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The SideKick plugin provides a framework for high-level language-specific features. Currently, this includes a structure tree dockable window, commands for moving the caret and folding based on language tokens, and a basic code-completion framework. The SideKick plugin does nothing by itself; at least one plugin providing a language parser, such as the XML plugin, must be installed.

PLUGIN.NAME: SmartOpen
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Matthieu Casanova
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: SmartOpen is another plugin that will help you to quickly open your files. It can index files from the folders you want, or from ProjectViewer It supports search from any part of your filename, or camelcase search. For example if you want a file named AbstractOptionPane.java you can search with AOP or AOPane or AbsOprP and all combinations you want

PLUGIN.NAME: Snipplr
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Ian Lewis
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: A plugin that allows posting and searching code snippets on Snipplr

PLUGIN.NAME: SourceControl
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Stuart Barlow
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The SourceControl plugin provides integration with source control systems, such as MS Visual Source Safe. In time it will allow integration with a range of source control systems. At present just MS Visual Source Safe is supported. To add a new system just implement the SourceControlInterface.java interface and create an options panel for any settings required by the new system.

PLUGIN.NAME: SpellCheck
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Eric Le Lay
Scott Willy
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
SpellCheck is an jEdit plugin to perform spell checking of text in a jEdit buffer. You will need to install Aspell (http://aspell.sf.net/) before using this plugin. Aspell is available for Windows and a variety of UNIX platforms.
This plugin provides: an jEdit action to spell check selected text, configurable location of the Aspell executable, spell check dialog to allow the user to validate each suspect word (the dialog has buttons for: Cancel, Change, Change All, Ignore, and Ignore All), it shows the suspect word, lists suggested replacements, and has a field where the user can type in the replacement word.

PLUGIN.NAME: SQL
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Sergey V. Udaltsov
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The SQLPlugin provides an interface for sending queries from a jEdit buffer or selection to database server using JDBC. Requires the JDBC 2.0 drivers for your database (tested with MySQL and Oracle).

PLUGIN.NAME: SshConsole
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Alan Ezust
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: SshConsole is an extension of the FTP, Console and ErrorList plugins designed to execute commands on the same host, and in the same directory, as the file you are currently editing or clicking on in the File Browser or ProjectViewer. Uses the sftp:// protocol and Console to parse the output for errors to show in ErrorList. Makes it easier to compile remote files and quickly jump to the errors.

PLUGIN.NAME: Substance
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Dale Anson
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The Substance Look and Feel plugin provides the Substance Look and Feel to jEdit.

PLUGIN.NAME: Sudoku
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Nigel Galloway
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: A board for playing, obtaing hints for, or solving Sudoku problems. It works best docked to the left of jEdit.

PLUGIN.NAME: SuperAbbrevs
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Sune Simonsen
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: This plugin gives you eclipse style code templates. You can define a template wich contains variables. You assosiate the template with a abbreviation, if you expand a template, the first variable will be selected. If you change the selected variable text, it vil be change everywhere in the template. You can use the TAB and Shift-TAB keys, to jump back and forth between the variables.

PLUGIN.NAME: SuperScript
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Jiger Patel
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: SuperScript is a scripting "Power House" plugin that supports scripting in 19 languages ranging from BML to Beanshell to Javascript to Jython to NetRexx to Perl to Ruby to XSLT to..... SuperScript uses Apache BSF to provide scripting support for 19 scripting languages. Using SuperScript you get one interface to your scripting language of choice without leaving jEdit. Read the included docs for more information about how to use SuperScript.

PLUGIN.NAME: SVNPlugin
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Dale Anson
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The SVNPlugin provides a tree browser for SVN repositories, and the ability to perform most SVN operations without leaving the editor.

PLUGIN.NAME: SynchroScroll
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Dale Anson
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: A plugin to allow syncrhonized scrolling between multiple text areas.

PLUGIN.NAME: SyntaxHelper
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Shlomy Reinstein
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
SyntaxHelper makes it easy to configure syntax highlighting styles in jEdit by providing the Syntax Highlighting option pane as a dockable window, that:
* Provides immediate feedback in the buffer when a syntax style is changed * Enables cancellation of changes to syntax styles * Makes it easy to configure the style of desired text by highlighting the style of the text under the caret.

PLUGIN.NAME: Tags
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Ollie Rutherfurd
Matthew Gilbert
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
The Tags plugin provides a set of navigation actions for working with "tag files" in the CTags format.
For jEdit 4.4 and later, Tags is not supported. Use CtagsInterface instead.

PLUGIN.NAME: TaskList
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Dale Anson
John Gellene
Ollie Rutherfurd
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: This plugin provides a dockable, tabular list of comments extracted from the text of a file being edited in jEdit. The display shows an icon representing the type of comment, the line where the comment appears and the comment text. You can jump to a comment by double-clicking on the corresponding row of the table. The comment text in the buffer can be highlighted as a user option.

PLUGIN.NAME: TEI
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Conal Tuohy
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
This plugin provides tools for text encoding using TEI XML
* A template menu provides starting points for creating new TEI documents * Schemas, templates, catalogs, and stylesheets are updated automatically from the TEI Consortium's website

PLUGIN.NAME: Templates
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Steve Jakob
Calvin Yu
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The Templates plugin allows dynamic generation of source code and other files based on template files. The incorporation of the Apache Velocity templating engine as of version 3.0.0 allows for a great deal of flexibility and interactivity. Templates may be accessed through the Plugins menu or a dockable tree view.

PLUGIN.NAME: TextAutocomplete
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Jakub Hol
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
TextAutocomplete collects "words" in the current buffer and those that you type and offers you automatically a list of possible completions as you type a new word. It's pretty similar to the jEdit's function "Complete Word" but it's automatic, you don't need to press any key to invoke the list of completions. The plugin was inspired by a similar functionality in OpenOffice.org.
The plugin is configurable, you can define what a "word" is, what words (not) to remember etc. - see the docs. It's also possible to modify manually the list of remembered words.
You have to start the autocompletion for every buffer where you want it.

PLUGIN.NAME: TextFilter
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Marcelo Vanzin
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: TextFilter allows the user to run text from a buffer through an external process and capture the output. It also allows actions to be created and assigned to shortcuts using jEdit's action mechanism.

PLUGIN.NAME: TextObjects
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Matthew Gilbert
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
The TextObjects plugin provides actions to select text. Currently it supports selecting words, sentences, paragraphs, code blocks, quotes, and comments.
To start using the plugin, bind a shortcut to the "Start TextObjects input handler". Then, to select a text object:
* Press the shortcut created above. * Then press 'a' or 'i' for a-object or in-object respectively. * Finally, press an object shortcut. The table below shows the shortcuts and their corresponding text blocks.
Shortcut Key Text Object w Word s Sentence p Paragraph { or ( or [or ] or } or ) Block - (entered character determines the type of block to select) " or ' or ` Quote - (entered character determines the quote block to select) c Comment

PLUGIN.NAME: TextTools
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: mike dillon
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
This plugin provides a number of small actions for performing text manipulation.
Currently, the package includes the Sort, Reverse Sort, Transpose Characters, Transpose Lines, and Transpose Words.
In addition, TextTools plugin offers the actions Toggle Line Comment and Toggle Range Comment.
See the plugin documentation for more details about the actions themselves.

PLUGIN.NAME: TomcatSwitch
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Amedeo Farello
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
The TomcatSwitch plugin allows for the creation and control of an external Jakarta Tomcat server process.
The plugin adds a shell to the JEdit Console plugin window, offering commands tostart, stop, restart and check the process status.
Output from Tomcat's stdout and stderr streams is reported to the console.

PLUGIN.NAME: TypoScript
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Neil Bertram
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The TypoScript plugin provides virtual filesystem support for loading and editing the "setup" and "constants" templates within the TYPO3 CMS, complete with a contributed edit mode allowing syntax highlighting. It interfaces with TYPO3 using XML-RPC, so you will need to install the jeditvfs extension in the TYPO3 backend (available from TER via the Extension Manager). A site browser dockable panel is included as a means for locating the template to load. Templates cannot be created from within jEdit; you must first create them in the backend as usual.

PLUGIN.NAME: Updater
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Shlomy Reinstein
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
The Updater plugin automates updates to jEdit. It can update to the latest point-release version (e.g. jEdit 5.5) or to the latest daily build. You can configure the plugin to run automatically on startup, or once in a few days when jEdit is running. It also offers an action to manually trigger an update.
When updating, it shuts down jEdit, and restarts it using the script of your choice (configurable from plugin options).

PLUGIN.NAME: Vimulator
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Niels Muendler
mike dillon
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
Vimulator is a vi-emulator for jEdit, bringing popular VIM keybindings to jEdit.
This project is a port of the jEdit Plugin Vimulator by mike dillon, modified to work for jdk 15 and jEdit 5.
This project is WIP, but already features
* vi-like navigation * basic commands (i.e. w,q) * insertion, replace and visual modes * the 3 visual modes, visual, visual block and visual line * yanking * multiple caret editing
Feedback and contributions are highly appreciated. See https://github.com/nielstron/vimulator

PLUGIN.NAME: VoxSpell
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Matthew Gilbert
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
The VoxSpell plugin checks the spelling of English language documents while you are typing, underlining the mispelled words whenever they are found. More languages may be supported in the future, contact the author if you're willing to help. It comes bundled with an English language dictionary produced from the SCOWL word list hosted at (Kevin's Word List Page).
Warning: the algorithm used to store the word suggestion list is unoptimized. This plugin consumes, typically, ~30MB of memory

PLUGIN.NAME: WhiteSpace
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Nathan Jones
Andre Kaplan
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The WhiteSpace plugin highlights normally invisible characters such as spaces, tabs, any other whitespace, and control characters. It also offers features to improve code readability and keep code consistently indented.

PLUGIN.NAME: XercesPlugin
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: apache.org
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: This plugin packages the documentation and binaries of Xerces-J version 2, as a jedit plugin.

PLUGIN.NAME: Xilize
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Andy Streich
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The XilizePlugin translates Xilize markup, a superset of Textile, for creation of rich XHTML pages making jEdit an efficient and very simple web content generation engine. The markup allows you to write sophisticated content in a natural way, and transformation can be done at four levels of granularity: text selection, buffer, directory, or directory tree. Xilize can automatically generate XHTML doctype declarations, the "head" element and its content, has provision for include files, conditional includes, defines, and can read Java property files.

PLUGIN.NAME: XInsert
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Eric Le Lay
Dominic Stolerman
Romain Guy
Martin Raspe
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The XInsert plugin provides a hierarchical clip manager that utilizes XML based library files.

PLUGIN.NAME: XML
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Dale Anson
Alan Ezust
Eric Le Lay
Robert McKinnon
Andre Kaplan
Slava Pestov
Martin Raspe
Jakub Roztocil
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
The XML plugin provides a SideKick tree structure browser for editing XML, HTML, CSS and JavaScript files, and completion for XML, HTML and CSS.
Matching tag actions, pretty-printing, graphical editing of tag attributes and conversion of special characters to entities and vice versa are supported for both XML and HTML files.
XML files are validated against their DTD, XSD, or RNG. Validation errors are shown in the Error List.

PLUGIN.NAME: XPTracker
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Brad Mace
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
The XPTracker plugin is for tracking project progress using Extreme Programming methodology.
Data is stored in a MySQL database so it is accessible to all developers as well as other programs, plugins, web pages, etc. Database setup is covered in the help files.

PLUGIN.NAME: XQuery
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Wim Le Page
Pieter Wellens
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION:
The XQuery plugin provides features for querying XML documents, setting options for output, performance monitoring and other XQuery processor specific variables.
The XQuery engine bundled with this plugin is the Saxon XQuery processor. But we designed the plugin to support other engines as well making use of a dynamic adapter system.

PLUGIN.NAME: Xrefactory
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Marian Vittek
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: Xrefactory is a refactoring browser. Is is a port of Emacs Xrefactory and is based on a shareware xref. It provides code completion, source browser (find definiton, find all usages, find unused symbols) class tree viewer, symbol retriever and a refactoring browser. Refactorings allow method extraction, safe symbol renaming, adding/removing/reordering of parameters, moving of fields and methods among classes, moving of classes among packages, etc. Refactorings are safe with detection of possible conflicts. Xrefactory is scaled to work with large projects.

PLUGIN.NAME: XSearch
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Alan Ezust
Rudi Widmann
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: XSearch is an extended search plugin, that provides a replacement for the built-in jEdit search/replace dialogs. It has awareness of the ProjectViewer plugin, and can restrict its search to the project file set. It uses gnu.regexp, instead of java.util.regex, which means it supports a slightly different syntax, and uses a different algorithm, which some say is more robust.

PLUGIN.NAME: XSLT
PLUGIN.AUTHOR: Eric Le Lay
Robert McKinnon
Greg Merrill
PLUGIN.DESCRIPTION: The XSLT plugin provides features for transforming XML documents using XSLT stylesheets and for searching XML documents using XPath expressions.
